case_vignette: A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department for right wrist pain and swelling 2 hours after falling on an outstretched hand while playing softball. The pain worsened when he attempted to pitch after the fall. He has eczema and type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and topical clobetasol. He appears uncomfortable. Examination shows multiple lichenified lesions over his forearms. The right wrist is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. There is tenderness to palpation in the area between the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, and extensor pollicis longus muscle. The thumb can be opposed actively towards the other fingers. Muscle strength of the right hand is decreased.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing pain and swelling in my right wrist, and it hurts more when I try to move it.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for about 2 hours.
Did you have any recent injury or unusual activity involving your wrist?
Yes, I fell on an outstretched hand while playing softball.
Is there any bruising, and can you move your fingers and wrist despite the pain?
There's no mention of bruising, but I have limited range of motion in my wrist due to the pain, although I can still move my fingers.
Have you had any previous injuries or issues with this wrist or any other joints?
No, I haven't mentioned any previous injuries or issues with this wrist or other joints.
**Final Diagnosis:** Wrist sprain

Despite the swelling and pain, the patient confirms the ability to move their fingers, though they have a limited range of motion in the wrist.
